values:
As of 2:38 this afternoon, I am officially done with my first semester of freshman year. 
What the fuck.
I am seventeen. That's it and it's not. I fuck around with it but it's still there it's still right. It's more deeply rooted than I ever think. How can I get older get past this. I can't.

Oh fuck.
So. At present, I'm afraid to go out of my room. Because. Shit. Uh. That was such a bad idea. If my student fellow group is not a bunch of rocks, I'm in serious shit. But they're laughing, so maybe not. Should I venture out? I don't know. I need to have a purpose. Like, I'll go to the bathroom. Yeah. 
Fuck.

I'm at Vassar.
Our room is tiny, but with our beds lofted my roommate Mariko and I can breathe well. Don't know how sleeping so high will turn out. It's awfully close to the ceiling. Whatever. It'll be great. It's Vassar.
My draw number is 553 out of 680 (Mariko's is 31), but my advisor is in the Anthropology dept, so I should be able to talk myself into Cultural Anthropology, and I've got the drive to really dig for Religions of Asia. English I can take or leave, and if I don't get into calculus I'll talk to Mr. Feroe. And I'm at Vassar, man. Isn't that awesome? It just feels so great. My roommate and I get along real well, Josh brought me a handle each of vodka and rum, so I've got some good times in the near future. My hair's a fucking afro from the rain, but I'm at Vassar. I have a key and a V-card and my Harvey poster and an awesome makeshift cardboard box hutch for my printer, and tomorrow I'll still have all those things. And more. So much more.
There's no way this can't be cool.

I got excited about turning 17 last night. Something about getting shot with lasers (because I suck at laser tag) and realizing that I'll be seing some people for the last time in quite a while, really makes me not care that I'll be young as fuck. Because I'll be so young, and what gets me there is fantastic. And hey, 17 is pretty great. I mean, I've never been 17 before, it should be a good time. I'll be older, I'll be able to consent and see R-rated movies, and I'll get as old as I think I want eventually. And I'm going to Vassar in one small week. One small, little week, man. Mmmmmm.
Timing has really sucked for me lately, though. Ugh.
But I got a new toy! Yeah, it's green.

UGH. Rain, man. What a downer.
I'm awfully disappointed.

Jewett 338!
I'm so stoked. I get the new bathrooms.

Bwahaha.
The College Board has confirmed that I royally suck at physics. Mmhmm. 2, man. And I'm pretty sure they don't give out 1's. But hey. I'm going to Vassar. In 43 days. The AP Physics exam is not. So who's the winner, here. Come on.
I'll get credit for English and US, though, which is cool.

So, apparently, every year Vassar has an author come lecture as part of the Freshman Course. This year, the lecturer is Salman Rushdie.
Yeah.
Salman Rushdie.
Mmmm, Vassar. 
I got the Freshman handbook and pre-registration stuff in the mail today. And stuff about the BSC, Bandana peolple, my pre-major advisor. I get an advisor. Ahh it's so real.
58 days, man. 58.

So.
I've found a new conundrum to get all worked up about, create wildly improbable schemes over, and generally use up time by forcing frenzied thought.
Vassar schedueling. Mmhmm. Specifically, single-variable calculus. The short-version is that in order to not have to take Elem. French at 9am EVERY MORNING FOR MY ENTIRE FRESHMAN YEAR, I need to magically be able to take Topics in single-variable calculus, not plain-old single-variable. Of course, Topics is for people with prior experience with calculus. Meaning, people who took AP calc in high school, and didn't do so hot. So, I thought, hey, I'm not doing much this summer except supposed to be working at a job I don't have, so why don't I find an online calc course (because a) if/when I do actually get a job, I'd have to schedule hours around a class at a university and, b) I'd have no/have to be worked out transportation to and from the class. Well, I'd have that same trouble with the job, what with my sucky driving skills, lack of license/car and all. But, whatever. ) to take over the summer, and get this exposure to calculus?
Meh. At least the process-part will use up Becca-shmoozing-watching bad television-time, regardless of the end result. Hell, if it actually works I'd have something to do over the summer, so I'm not a complete vegetable by August 27th.
In other news, 3 days til graduation, 68 til Vassar. 6-8! Man.

19 days til graduation, 84 til Vassar.
Yeah, that pretty much sums it up.
Senior banquet was tonight. It was great, actually. A little awkward at first, what with the being on a boat, mozerella sticks and all. But then it got better. There were fireworks, which was cool. Pretty fantastic night, all in all. And oh gosh. I wore a pretty dress from H&M. It's nice to wear pretty dresses. Well, one at a time. Gets a little bulky, otherwise.
Aarghm, I have to do an entire, humungoid AP Physics project on AP Physics that I don't know. For Monday. 
Ugh I should really go to sleep. I'm not quite sure why I wrote this.

Holy crap. I almost forgot the disclaimer at the beginning of the APUS exam. On the page facing the first questions, on top of some weird don't-read-me-from-the-cover pattern, was this bit about how the College Board doesn't endorse the content of the exam, they just have some panel who picks questions reflecting the curriculum. Seemed too, cautious. I'd kinda thought we'd gotten through that.

Despite it's disappointments, APs and general lack of anything besides a dress for prom, this week was actually pretty fantastic.
NYSSMA Majors was Monday. We got gold. Our 14th gold, but the break of the 5 or 6 year gold with distinction streak. Tocatta did us in. Matt overheard the adjudicators saying just that- -up until Tocatta we had it. King Cotton was solid. Fanfare and Allegro was the best we've ever played it, easily. But Tocatta, man. It just wasn't together at all. Ugh. Hopefully we can pull it together some before Virginia, but it probably won't be enough to win. Our competition is only one other band, but they're from California. You don't come to an eastcoast music competition from California if you suck. Even if you're mediocre. That's the weird thing about the festival this year. It's mostly choral. There are no other orchestras, no other jazz bands, just choirs. Uch. Now we'll have to listen to a lot of flat altos, shrill sopranos and nonexistent male voices, instead of mediocre bands or jazz bands. It almost seems hardly worth the bother, except for the day at Bush Gardens. That's what everyone is looking forward to.
I stayed home Tuesday. Wasn't feeling fantastic. That meant that I went to AP physics and econ once, and pre-calc and German none at all this week. And I gotta say, it felt nice.
Sooo. APs. They actually weren't atrocious, or anything. English was, meh. The multiple choice were killer. There was this one awfully goofy question, something along the lines of 'which of the following words rhymes with the sound the cue-owl mentioned in line 4987675768 might make?' Yeah, goofy. And I didn't do well on the essays. The first was my best- -some hawk poem, actually pretty nice. The second, the passage, was so disappointing. It was some generic, lord-lady-duchess "let's talk about the roles of men and women as if it's exciting and foreign and taboo." And it was Wilde, too. But they picked such a crappy passage. You couldn't do anything with it, and I was really looking forward to doing a lot with it. And I mean a lot. Putting words and letters in boxes and feeling like John Nash. It's so cool, but I couldn't do it. Dinky passage. And the final essay was severe crap. The closing sentence was, "This is still pretty bad, but I'm still going to college."
APUS was pretty good. The multiple choice were much more doable than that of the English, but the DBQ was the most awkward and uncharacteristically phrased question I have ever seen. There was no clear, defined numerical time period, just some indicating words. And it was fluffy. Women and republican motherhood and cult of domesticity and crap. But but but I worked in the establishment of Vassar College in 1861, the same year civil war broke out. It was definitely the best piece of outside information I've used in a DBQ. Ever. And then the two thematics. The first was a choice between comparing the Spanish and British colonies in the Americas (which absolutely no one chose) and discussing how the role of the federal government changed during the Civil War. I did the latter, and had to discuss two of the following: race relations, econoic development and/or westward expansion. I pulled off the first, but drew a complete and total blank on the last two. I made up some junk about westward expansion, then went on a tangent about some funk lyrics. Then I crossed it out, because I actually felt pretty good about my other writing, and thought that a bad essay would score better than a bad essay with funk lyrics. Mrs. Ferris aside, I don't think most of the APUS graders have much of a sense of humor. But the second thematic was solid. The question dealt with rebelling (which they referred to as 'critiquing') against the conformity of 1950s America, by discussing two: youths, civil rights activists and intellectuals. So I talked about rock and roll, chicken and tight pants for youths, then the Beat generation, Ginsberg's obscenity trial and such for intellectuals. I practically used word for word what I wrote in my 'American Artifacts Are Awesome' project. I was definitely riding a wave of luck on the APUS exam.
I have nothing figured out for prom. My dress is beautiful, as are my shoes, but they don't match. I don't have a date, I don't have a ticket, I don't have a table. I don't really want to figure any of it out. It's too late to ask anyone, not like I'd actually have the courage to do so. But my dress is so ridiculously pretty. I just want to wear it and look pretty for a little while. Not really infront of all the people from my school, because, frankly, I've stopped trying to look cool/good/likethey'dwanttobefriendswithme infront of them. I'm going to Vassar awfully soon. They aren't. And that's fine. It just sucks going through another month and a half of this. It's draining.

I definitely almost died when the Katrina character told Milo Ventimiglia's character that he "will make some Vassar girl very happy someday." cdsoiljkesduijkf.
Yes, I watch The Bedford Diaries just to see Milo Ventimiglia. The show itself is pretty awful.
Despite the fact that I got a 77 in AP Physics (lowest average ever), I swung a 93.78 overall. I am rockin senioritis.
The Vassar Open House was great, though unnecessarily rainy. It feels different. I don't feel like I'm sneaking in, like it isn't mine. It's mine this time. And it feels phenomenal.
NYSSMA Majors is Monday. Toccatta Marziale is, we'll see. Yeah, that bad.

SUNY Geneseo and UBuffalo Admissions need some new management.
What's the rationale in sending out SUNY general applications to applicants after the general application has been recieved by SUNY Admissions? Furthermore, why send it out after the formal deadline, especially when it states in the cover letter that the application deadline is January 15? And why is the UB supplement in a fucking knothole of the online application, with no mention of it anywhere else on the website or in the extra SUNY general application from UB?
Fucking excess.

It smelled like woodsmoke this morning. I couldn't appreciate it because of the wall(s) of mucas in my nose. I love the smell of woodsmoke.
Rome was nice. Loud firecrackers in trash cans. Metro that shuts down at 9PM. A loss of respect for CNN because CNNWorld (the only English channel we got) ran exactly five stories a day, one of which was always the terrible weather in Europe. And there was some weird, loud, burst-y British newscaster. Pretty ruins.Tasty pizza and lasagna (oh, I dropped the vegetarian thing. Through evaluation I realized that I had only adopted it because I was tired of eating chicken marinated in salad dressing. And the SIG food at that time sucked [remember the awful catering days? One particular dinner sticks out in my mind- -SIG was trying to do Chinese, and one girl came out as we were going in, saying, "I came, I saw, I got ice cream."]. Now I'm tired of eating pasta and sauce. Eating animal reopens new doors, more variety, more possibility that I can make dinner and the rest of my family [parents, mostly] will eat it and not deem it necessary to supplement it with some enormous amount of meat that will last the better part of a week. And make me feel special. Maybe even useful, purposeful. It'd be nice.). And I could walk most places, supplemented with the Metro. I liked being able to just walk everywhere, not have to be confined by my lack of driving experience/license. Makes me wonder that I might actually enjoy living in a city, as opposed to a small town. I suppose I just figured I would want to be in a small town for college and such. Now I wonder why. But I know. Maybe a city is the right place for me for the next portion of my life. I'd like/I need opportunity. Opportunity that I can grasp readily. Something beyond food chains and high school. Is a college in a city more likely to have that than a college in a small town? Or does the location even matter. Maybe it's just college I'm craving. Maybe the location is just a red herring.
But I do like being able to walk places. And gelato is ridiculously good.
I've been drinking water, because I feel bad for my body only getting tasty Mountain Dew and the occasional glass of milk.
Two more applications to do. NYU and Haverford.
I'm getting pretty used to wearing my hair down.
Watched most of "Firefly" this weekend. Beat doing work. Still don't like the fake cowboy-speak.
I made macaroni and cheese tonight. It was tasty.
I should probably stop with the short lines. Bye.

Vassar C.
Brandeis U.
Boston C.
NYU.
Haverford C.
Bowdoin C. (?)
Colgate U. (?)

Is it silly that I'm now selecting colleges to apply to based on whether or not they have a major/minor that I know nothing about but think might have something to do with what I spent last advanced comp fiddling around with?
I thought not.

Dear German project,
Stop being such an ass.
We actually did you, so return the favor. Write yourself to a CD in some readable/usable program, without splicing the beginning with scenes from the end of the tape.
That'd be cool, thanks.
Love, Becca

I saw Roy Cohn.
Like, actually saw video of him. Not some mention in a history text or a character/charicature played by Al Pacino. It was weird.
In other news, Nathan's jazz battle was fucking amazing. He definitely won.

My Swarthmore application is done. Signed, sealed, delivered, I'm yours.
I saw 'Sweeney Todd' in NYC this weekend. Patty Lipone's voice is, not what it used to be. The staging was, weird. The characters were the orchestra. Hence, the vocal performances were compromised. Lipone 'played' the tuba, a whole two notes. It was only for gag purposes. The story had a few little holes. It got a bit predictable towards the end; the accordian player (yes, a woman in drag was playing the accordian) brought out a white coat stained with blood before someone died. Ate some tasty Thai food afterwards.
I wrote about PIG and its inadequacies for my college essay. Weird, but it might work.
My grandmother met Katharine Hepburn in the early 40s. She fucking met Katharine Hepburn. !
I've been listening to Nina Simone's 'Misunderstood' a lot latetly. I'm really digging it.
I'm going to fucking Italy.

Pff.

The link my background picture was from died. And I don't have the patience to search for a new background picture.

Bother.

Last night I wrote something for advanced comp that I actually felt. I had forgotten what it felt like, to write something real and meaningful. I felt solid. I feel solid.

Today was something I haven't had in a while. Fidgetting, tapping and grooving to music inside me, being restless. I've been stagnant. For a while. I'm back to restless. It feels nice.

I definitely suck at dodgeball, but I think some boy was looking at me. Which would be cool. I need something to do.

There's a lunar eclipse tomorrow. If the sky is overcast because Bush didn't sign and implement the Kyoto Protocol so global warming is taking its karmic revenge with hurricanes so we get after-effects of rain and uck I am going to write him a nasty letter. It'll be long and vicious and educated.

That's it.

My scarf is a foot long. It grew a stitch about 5" in.

Peach pie never tastes as good as I think it should.

Co-rdu-roy. Feels so nice.

Mmm, Swarthmore. Still feels right. In fact, it feels even more right. I went to an 8:30 (gaah!) freshman philosophy seminar. It was in this wooden room with bare bookshelves. The class was comfortable. There was discussion, banter, accusations and proof. It felt like what learning should be. Notes in the margins and everything. A bunch of ML kids were in the class, and they were all ridiculously nice. Then I went to an astronomy/physics class. I liked the professor, and the general feel of the class. Then a tour and lunch at Tarbles. Then the interview. It was pretty nice, actually. I explained graduating early and spoke a lot about Mr. Giroux. I also talked about the phenomenal sentence in Their Eyes Were Watching God, Matilda, SIG (briefly, surprisingly), Vassar and my parents, how I hated Mr. Jones. It seemed to go well. Then we went back to the hotel and relaxed, and I tried to contact Gil and visit him, but it didn't work. Which, sucked. Then I slept, and woke up and went home. And now I'm not doing homework. And imagining ridiculously improbable situations. Because, y'know, I have to do something.

So, first day of senior year. My scheduel is fine and dandy.

Block 1: AP Physics- Fedoroff -ABDE
             P.E.- Bernardi -CF
Block 2: Concert Band- Giroux -ACE
             Pre-Calc- Batty -BDF
Block 3: Advanced Comp- Sankowski -ACE 1st Semester
             AP English- MacDonald -ACE 2nd Semester
             German IV- Kramer -BDF
Block 4: AP U.S. History- Ferris-Fearnside -ACE
             Particiation in Government- Larson -BDF 1st Semester
             Economics- Thomas -BDF 2nd Semester

Mr. Harrington looks shorter. There's a new Rent-A-Cop. I have yet to see the new principal.

I'm aching for some solid trombone-sounds.

My ears have been real sensitive to pressure and elevation changes lately. Yesterday my mom and I were driving and all of a sudden my ears/head/whatever it is went crazy. They're doing that a little now, too. Oh, silly Becca-parts.

I should really order some new contacts. These are getting a little fuzzy.

Pep band played at the home game tonight. I've missed Mr. Giroux. He's so fantastic. The three Giroux boys played with pep band- -Mr, Nate (Little Giroux) and Tyler (Littler Giroux). It was adorable. Pep band felt pretty nice. I saw Mr. Kramer at the game and waved to him. I've missed Kramer, too.

I'm tired.

mgdseu5i7678iuhjk.

I just ate a real tasty taco. Mmm, taco.

I need to write a paper on nuclear proliferation for APUS. As in, actually do research and then write on it. Before the eighth. Pff. Lazy lazy lazy Becca.

My computer has corduroy pants.

I'm older.

My parents got me my college-laptop. It feels weird. Makes sense, as I'm not the most technologically adept of beings and could use more than just a summer to get used to the computer I'll use for the duration of my college experiences, but still feels weird. I'm getting my senior picture taken tomorrow.

Josh got me some Nina Simone ( Misunderstood, if I remember correctly) and Velvet Underground ( Loaded and The Velvet Underground & Nico). Mmm, music.

I named my laptop Malachi.

So, Becca went to orchestra camp. Not band camp, orchestra camp. There is a solid difference between the two. Orchestra camp doesn't have enough low brass, and STRINGS DO NOT BREATHE! It's so weird. I haven't been exposed to string players very much.

I've lived the last four weeks in a turquoise cabin with a clarinetist and pianist from Hartford and a cellist from Cleveland. I've discovered that serious violinists and violist get these hickey-looking things on their necks from the impact of their instrument. I've lived entire days in my pajamas with my hair down. I really do talk in my sleep. Frequently.

The first day there my dad and I drove up behind a car with a Swarthmore sticker. The bassonist's sister inside the car is going to be a freshman there, tomorrow. I spoke with her today and she was very nice and excited and gave me her e-mail. Swarthmore increases in appeal every day.

There was this counselor, Nate, who was very tall. His face would not express anything specific. He lived in this old green trailer. Next to this, nestled in the woods, was Gnomenmenschia. A land of gnomes. He plays viola. I'm going to miss Nate.

The percussion counselor's left eye would twitch.

There was a trombonist counselor, Dylan. I was quite attracted to him. He was one of the assistant conductors, and would use cute conductor-analogies. They were adorable. He was adorable. He played at one of the faculty concerts in a low brass trio- -trombone, french horn and tuba. It was absolutely fantastic. It was followed by a tuba solo and a euphonium solo (the latter sounded like a cuddly teddy bear). The performance of those three pieces was one of the two things that I truly got excited (altough that's not the correct word) about at camp, the second of which I will explain later. One day we woodwinds were having a sectional in the chapel. It was pouring, and these ginormous (yeah, ginormous) white spiders came spinning down on their web-threads. One was inches away from Dylan's head (he was leading the rehearsal) until he ran away. Dylan, not the spider. So we tried to rehearse in the practice rooms at the back of the chapel, but the light bulbs didn't work. So Dylan took his shirt off (! It was quite unexpected and not fully necessary but very enjoyable) and wrapped it around other bulbs, to try and put them in the practice rooms so we would have light to practice. It didn't work. He plays frisbee a lot. With his shirt off.

There were two kids from Venezuela, one from Columbia, Israel (she was sooo pretty), France and Turkey. I was kind of with the guy from Turkey, Emil Erten, for a few days, then didn't like him anymore. I do that a lot. It's probably because I don't really like them. I'd just like to. Also, I didn't like the constant hand-holding thing. It got to be habit, not excitement. When things like that become habit they lose their importance, they lose their meaning. I'm not sure if he understood that in the way that I do.

The orchestra conductor, Mr. Peltz, had very condescending facial expressions. I didn't like him. I miss Mr. Giroux. I'm going to give him a big hug the first day of school.

I didn't like many things about the program.

The nurse was a complete doofus. My roommate was complaining of cramps, so he offered to take her temperature. He didn't even have a heating pad. Pff.

One day two counselors went on the PA system and had this fake conversation about how people shouldn't be playing frisbee before the concert, but rather should practice or get dressed. It was completely uncalled for. The gall of those people. So I asked my roommate calmly if she would like to go play frisbee with me. And we did.

The second thing I got truly excited about (by this I mean the way I was when I was chasing the moon through the clouds at SIG last summer) was when writing a petition to have a dance. I racked my brain for the correct wordings and phrases for an entire day. I felt alive.

This entry didn't have a solid beginning, and I don't have the noun for solid ending, so, eat some cake.

It finally feels like tomorrow will be my birthday. I got a purple calculator keychain from SIG.

Goodbye air conditioning and computer, hello rustic (read: shockingly bright blue cabins and...??? I do not know) music camp!

No cell phone, no interweb til the 21st (not like I talk on them anyway).

P.S. I definitely had a dream about Jared Finklestien last night. !

So, I've been taking this online writing course through CTY, and the most recent assignment was to research and elaborate on the meanings and history of my name(s). In his comments about my name meaning "bound" or "tied" in Hebrew (as so many online baby name meaning sites have gleefully informed me in pink font [denoting that "Rebecca" is a girl's name, of course!]), my instructor wanted me to work in "how you feel you represent--or don't represent--these interesting definitions."

I had to giggle.
Gosh, I completely forgot. I got a bikini. Yeah. It's pretty. My ankle feels dry.

I got Part I of the application for Oberlin today. It feels strange. I've been sitting staring at those words for seventeen minutes and it still feels strange.

I think I always remember people looking and sounding different than they are. At least if I haven't seen them a whole lot. I remember I was 'dating' (middle school) this one guy, and I had only seen him like, once, and I kept trying to remember details about his face so that I would recognize him the next time I saw him. I felt bad when I couldn't remember what color his eyes were. I can't really remember the color of anyone's eyes. I think that's because I don't look people in the eye. I think I looked Dave in the eye. I can't remember. But I always remember him looking and sounding different than he is. I keep typing sounging instead of sounding. Pff.

I also got the Swarthmore Viewbook.

Michael Chertoff looks pretty creepy. Maybe he should get some sleep instead of being on C-SPAN at 12:06 AM.

Trotsky murder weapon may have been found.

Crazy.

S 130.05 Sex offenses; lack of consent.
  1. Whether or not specifically stated, it is an element of every
offense defined in this article, except the offense of consensual
sodomy, that the sexual act was committed without consent of the victim.
3. A person is deemed incapable of consent when he or she is:
  (a) less than seventeen years old; or

S 130.25 Rape in the third degree.
  A person is guilty of rape in the third degree when:
2. Being twenty-one years old or more, he or she engages in sexual
intercourse with another person less than seventeen years old; or
Rape in the third degree is a class E felony.
S 130.30 Rape in the second degree.
  A person is guilty of rape in the second degree when:
  1. being eighteen years old or more, he or she engages in sexual
intercourse with another person less than fifteen years old; or
It shall be an affirmative defense to the crime of rape in the second
degree as defined in subdivision one of this section that the defendant
was less than four years older than the victim at the time of the act.
  Rape in the second degree is a class D felony.
S 130.35 Rape in the first degree.
  A person is guilty of rape in the first degree when he or she engages
in sexual intercourse with another person:
  4. Who is less than thirteen years old and the actor is eighteen years
old or more.
  Rape in the first degree is a class B felony.

S 130.75 Course of sexual conduct against a child in the first degree.
  1. A person is guilty of course of sexual conduct against a child in
the first degree when, over a period of time not less than three months
in duration:
(b) he or she, being eighteen years old or more, engages in two or
more acts of sexual conduct, which includes at least one act of sexual
intercourse, deviate sexual intercourse or aggravated sexual contact,
with a child less than thirteen years old.
Course of sexual conduct against a child in the first degree is a
class B felony.
S 130.80 Course of sexual conduct against a child in the second degree.
  1. A person is guilty of course of sexual conduct against a child in
the second degree when, over a period of time not less than three months
in duration:
(b) he or she, being eighteen years old or more, engages in two or
more acts of sexual conduct with a child less than thirteen years old.
Course of sexual conduct against a child in the second degree is a
class D felony.
You can find the full thing here:

http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/nycodes/c82/a29.html
So, the age of consent is 17 in New York, but not everything is really illegal?

Yes, I was just asked by a boy 4 and 1/2 years my senior to go to the Corner (no, not the streetcorner. Rather, an ice cream place) after band rehearsal with "everyone".
Yes, in the above conversation I did an incredibly seductive thing with my eyes.
Yes, Dave (boy's name) did the same thing back.
Yes, I would have pounced on Dave had we not been in a really public place (he IS a trombonist and according to Josh, trombonists are phenomenal kissers).
Yes, Dave went to both of the Dave Matthew's Band concerts at SPAC, even Friday, with the torrential downpours and thunder and lighting.
Yes, Dave asked how old I was.
Yes, I replied truthfully.
Yes, the reaction was amazing. I'm getting too good at this.
Yes, I believe this little flirtation is over. He really did throw his head back in stupefied disbelief when I told him. Needless to say, yes, I would jump at the chance to know Dave more.
And yes, I managed to do all of this with a beetle stuck in my hair. Pff. Take that, you leggy blondes.

No more sophmore or junior years of high school. No more high school 'til September.

For now, I have Mountain Dew in the new packaging and promises of summer. And right now, that's enough.

Gah!

So this bright idea of taking an English class over the summer at SUNY Albany was great until I realized that the pamphlet was wrong and the class starts at 8:30 AM. 8:30! It takes more than half an hour to get to Albany which means leaving before eight which means getting up before seven if I aim to take a morning shower. I think the morning shower is gone. Grah!

In other news, Josh and I watched "I Heart Huckabees" yesterday. I like Dustin Hoffman. Loads. I had my dance recital Tuesday. My dance costume, although excessively like that of Minnie Mouse, does the most fantastic of things when I twirl. It flares out, practically level to the ground, up at my waist. That almost makes up for the bad "jazz" music and costumes. Almost.

No more 82-minute blocks until September.

Shockingly soon I will be a rising senior.

The passing of time is fantastic.

There is a slightly irreverant character in Trollope's miniseries "The Barchester Chronicles." He is bearded and wears a coat with lapels practically identical to those on Gil's coat, as I remember them.

All I want to do is sleep.

He's not done yet.

Ok. This is going to stop. Meaning, tonight I will do sit-ups and finish Lolita. Yes, finish. And within a week I will finish House of Leaves. And I will stop watching TV and being lazy and useless all day. When I do watch TV it will be C-SPAN or the Style Channel, because, whether I like to admit it or not, I like looking at pretty things. And I will stop eating excessively. It's getting ridiculous. And I will find things to do during the summer. Like a music camp. And somewhere to take Economics and Physics. And I will find a job somewhere. Maybe Hollywood Video. I like movies. And I will get through Mr. Jones' classes. And I will try to not storm out of classrooms, even though teachers are being terribly disrepectful towards history, think teaching is the practice telling instead of help discovering and/or just not worth my time. And I will do well next year. And I will make Swarthmore want me. And I will be looking at this entry many many times in the not so distant future because I know I will try to slug off and not do the collective it.

Slodged through school today. It was shortened, prom and all. I walked into the railing of a staircase. Now I'm watching C-SPAN. I caught a little of the Princeton fillibuster earlier. Right now, last year's Nobel Peace Prize Winner Wangari Muta Maathai is speaking. About environmental issues/responsibilities. Including the need to plant trees. Trees. Mmm. My ears are doing funny things.
Mmm, hear that? That's the sweet, sweet ringing of "Gold with Distinction".

So: Oberlin is flat. And has incredibly impressive science facilities. And didn't grab me like Swarthmore did/has. And is flat. I need me some differing degrees of elevation. And I must say, Main's gymnasium-hallways are growing in appeal with each college dormitory visit.
It's always fun when Josh visits. Even if we didn't go see "Spin City".
Papa is in the emergency room/hospital, but should be all right in a bit.
It was misty yesterday. Driving down for the seder, with all those mountains and trees (ohh, trees) shrouded in mist, mmmmm.
Bdah, I'm sooo lazy. Cmon, world. Give me something to stop being lazy for.

Went to NYC yesterday with the Drama Club to see "The Producers". It was actually an alright time. Shane wanted to go to Barnes & Noble, so we went. I picked up a copy of "Howl". Then we went to H&M and looked at pretty things. Then walked around a whole lot- -we didn't *really* know where we were going. Ended up walking by the UN. Stopped in some deli/grocery store and had some lunch. Then it got to be one, and we didn't know which way the theatre was (we were on 44th east, but needed to be on west and didn't know which way west was). So we were just walking one way, hoping it was the right one. I asked some nice girl which way 44th west was, and she said the opposite way we had been walking, but that she sometimes gets turned around (she seemed like such an adjective person, I was strongly tempted to give up "The Producers" plight and just sit down comfortably and speak with her. But, that did not happen). We chatted a bit while crossing the street, and then she went one way wishing us luck. So we walked a bit more, got quite a bit more anxious. I asked another nice lady which way 44th west was, and she pointed in the direction we were walking. I thanked her, and we chatted a bit more. Then we continued walking and finally found the St. James theatre, and saw the show. It was, very showy. Not really my thing, but, it was something to do. There were also a whole lot of suggestive referrences, to the point where it seemed quite excessive. The two men who were starring didn't have terrifically strong singing voices. By the end, the Broderick-character's voice was very thin, and not quite getting all the way up to his pitches. And the Lane-character did the whole yelling/singing thing, which I don't enjoy at all. On the whole, it was alright, but not really my thing. I definitely enjoyed "Wicked" more.

Tuseday we're going to head out to Ohio, and visit Oberlin College. And, maybe something else? Seems like I should. Driving all the way out to Ohio and back, and just visit one school? But I'm not quite sure where. Maybe I'll figure it out.

So, NYSSMA. 6 hours and 10 minutes ago. My (now) only shot at All-State. It came, and it went. I got a 97. A 97. A 97 does not get a flute into All-State.

I started off the first movement, by flubbing the theme. The theme! Bgaar! The piece went on. I missed notes, squashed a few rhythms. That was to be expected. Then, the second movement. Oh, the second movement. That's home. It's what I love to play. The passionate, flowing pieces, where you vary the intensity of each measure. That's what I dig. And the adjudicator cut me off. He cut.me.off. Before I even got to the second page of the movement. Mrrr, he cut me off and asked me to play scales, and I thropped (threw+plopped. Shut up.) my stand down so that I was facing him, and pounded the scales out. Then I couldn't find the feel for the sight-reading piece until the second (of two) line.

I have no one but myself to blame. I didn't practice until, about a month before the festival. I wasn't focused. I haven't been focused. I can't find my focus, or even something to focus on? The only thing I've been remotely focused on is sleep. And sleep hasn't been so rewarding. I sleep, yet I'm always tired, unmotivated. Unmotivated. So, I think I'm going to cut back. I'm tired of wasting my time, even the shortened time before I graduate. I'm going to try and use it. Try to live outside of high school. Try to stop wasting away.  Try to live, instead of just move.

Oh, and I played with my dinos in Global today.

-EDIT-

The adjudicator said I had good hand position. Baah, my hand position is terrible. That's one of the things my teacher rides me on. My terrible hand position. Pff.
